p
Class View

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          javax.swing.JComponent
              p.View
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.KeyListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener
 class View
extends javax.swing.JComponent
implements java.awt.event.KeyListener

The view layer in the MVC architectrue.
The view consists of:

  • 2 game scene parts, which is a view of the players and their environment including the land,
  • 2 player status parts where we can see heights, our shield, and our weapon reloading status,
  • one minimap of the whole land.

Author:
Andras Belicza

Method Detail

newGame

public void newGame()
Does all neccessary things for starting a new game.

getRGBOfHeight

private int getRGBOfHeight(float height)
Calculates and returns the RGB components of the color of the specified height on the landscape.
The returned int value contains the rgb values in the right order. Blue is at the least significant bits. All of the rgb components are 8 bit precision.

Parameters:
height - height whose color needed to be calculated
Returns:
the RGB values of the specified height on the landscape

interpolateColors

private int interpolateColors(java.awt.Color value1,
                              java.awt.Color value2,
                              double ratio)
Linear-interpolates colors. Calculates a 3rd color at a specified position between 2 boundary colors.
The position is specified by a ratio, whose value means: 0 => value1, 1 => value2, 0 < ratio < 1 => somewhere between value1 and value2.
In case of colors, interpolation means interpolation of red, green and blue components of colors.

Parameters:
value1 - first value of interpolation
value2 - last value of interpolation
ratio - where between value1 and value2 we need the interpolation
Returns:
the RGB value of the linear interpolation of value1 and value2 at a position between them specified by ratio

registerObjectMark

public void registerObjectMark(MovingObject object)
Registers a mark of a moving object.
Mark of a moving object can be like a bullet hitting the land, a rocket exploding into the land or a player crashing into the land.
Registering means displaying it somehow on the scene.
Implementation simply draws to the landscape. Drawing to the landscape cannot be done directly. Landscape is a very big (n*10MB) image, drawing into it is very slow (would make the game lag). First we make a subimage of it which has a small size, and we draw into that subimage.

Parameters:
object - object whose mark is to be registered

paint

public void paint(java.awt.Graphics g)
Paints the actual look of the component, paints the view of the game.
I would have used paintComponent(), but paint() is shorter, less space. I draw only to the Graphics2D object, doesn't matter... I'm sorry for being space centric... (but that's one of the competition's aspect) First draws the scenes, then the status windows, the minimap and lastly the potential messages.

Overrides:
paint in class javax.swing.JComponent
Parameters:
g - the graphics context in which to paint
